body.p:
Richmond Kentucky
Sept 12th 1865
Hon. Thos E. Bramlette
Governor of Kentucky

The undersigned citizens of Madison County Kentucky, respectfully represent that during the Winter of 1864 in a sudden affray Franklin Morris stabed Andrew Thomsburg in this County both being Citizens of the same.
At the March Term 1865 of the Madison Circuit Court Franklin Morris Ennis Morris and Richard Morris were all indicted for the murder of Andrew Thornsburg.

The only weapon used as established by the proof ^at the Examining Court^ was a Knife -- no other weapon than a Pocket Knife has ever been seen. There was no proof that Richard Morris struck any blows, although he was present.
The reason for including him in the indictment is obvious.

John W. Thornsburg the Father of the man who was stabed & from which he died, was Foreman of the Grand Jury that indicted the Morriss -- By including Richard Morris in the indictment, Franklin Morris was cut off from the benefit of his testimony -- Besides being the Foreman of the Grand Jury, John W Thornsburg has also employed two able Lawyers to prosecute Franklin Morris.
The Morriss are very poor and being unable to give bail they have been lying in Jail for nearly three months. Richard Morris is between 15 & 16 years of age -- about 15 years of age when the difficulty occured

We are satisfied there is no proof tending to show that Richard Morris was guilty of the Murder of Andrew Thornsburg, or even participated in the affray -- He had no weapon of any kind & being small & slender he could have rendered no assistance -- Considering his extreme Youth we earnestly pray your Excellency to grant said Richard Morris an immediate Pardon & relieve him from the unjust indictment against him.

We Peter T. Phelps & Wm Williams who held the Examining Court for the trial of the Morriss state that from the Evidence before us Richard Morris is deserving more even of Executive Clemency than Ennis Morris.

Peter T Phelps one of the justices that tried the Morris's
Wm Williams one of the Justices that tried the Morises
R. D. Davis
James H. Embry
R. R. Harris
John Bennett
Wm. J. Walker
V B Norries
L, D, Mauprin
E G Broaddus
We concur in the prayer of the foregoing Petition.
